review_title: Not really tactical, but very good for general use
reviews:
I have tactical flashlights, and they have their place in my stable. This is not really a tactical flashlight, but that is okay for certain of my uses around the house. I actually like that this unit defaults to low power, which you then need to up-cycle to higher power settings if desired. Great for using when you wake up in the middle of the night, but don't want to fully awaken to 10 million candlepower!

It also has these features I like/expect in a flashlight: excellent water-proofing, recessed tail switch, and you can stand it up in a "lantern" mode.

This flashlight runs for a nice, long time on low power, and uses up all of an AA. At the "dead" point, alkalines read about 0.4 - 0.5V open-circuit. That's pretty impressive. I intend to use lithium AA's once I finish off the factory alkalines (lithiums have higher energy density, are relatively insensitive to cold/heat, and don't leak, unlike alkalines).

If you don't need anti-roll features, the defensive front "wave," or powering on to high as a default, this is a great flashlight.

reviews:
The E12 has proven to be an outstanding multi-purpose flashlight. I know that it's popular with the EDC (everyday carry) crowd, but even if you aren't into that you will be pleased with it. I ended up buying several: one for the glovebox of my car, one for my toolbox, and another for around-the-house tasks.

There is certainly no shortage of rugged LED flashlights these days, but the E12 has been a winner in my book for a few reasons. First, it uses a single AA battery. A lot of these ultra-bright ones that are best-sellers on Amazon need a lithium battery that costs $10 or more. No way am I throwing that kind of money away on batteries for a flashlight that only gets occasional use. Another reason I'm loving the E12 is because of the size. It's small enough to hold in the palm of your hand without feeling like you'll misplace it or drop it, yet can also be maneuvered into tight spaces like the engine bay of a car or behind furniture. The third reason I bought a few of these is that they're able to take a lot of punishment. The one in my toolbox has been dropped onto concrete repeatedly, smacked against objects in my car's engine bay, and has suffered some accidental blows from my wrenches and hammer -- and it just keeps on ticking.

The E12 has three brightness modes but I rarely find myself using anything other than the dimmest setting. If anything, the highest setting is only for use in very dark environments such as a forest in the dead of night. I tried using the brightest setting while working on my car and found it to be overpowering: it simply reflected off everything and made me squint.

For the price paid I think it's really hard to beat this. It fits just about anywhere and uses cheap/readily available batteries. It'll take abuse without any issues and I won't cry if it does break (since it was only about $20). I can't bring myself to spend $100 on some of these fancier ones when you can get 95% of the performance and quality for so much less.

Note: picture shows my nearly three year old light beside a AA battery as a size reference.

I've got a Fenix E12 that I've carried in my pocked every day since I bought it from Amazon on 2017-Jan-12 (so almost three years). The black coating has worn off all the corners so it's now black/silver. It's gone swimming in oil, fallen on rocks while camping, fallen on concrete/asphalt, and banged up against keys/coins/etc. without issue; it keeps going as long as I keep throwing AA batteries in it. At one point I thought my two year old lost it and that night I was looking online for a replacement (luckily I found the original one behind furniture). I now recommend this flashlight to anyone who asks.

review_title: Owned for 5 years, the best light for my purposes
reviews:
I own numerous flashlights for numerous applications.
My applications for this light numbered from most frequent to least: 1) Walking my dog before sunrise and at night to look out for people, poop, varmints and a signal for cars so they don't hit us. 2) I work in an animal facility that occasionally require nightly health checks. 3) Random day to day situations that require a light.

So I bought this light when I was looking for a small single AA powered light that I can easily carry everyday. I chose this light for its three levels of brightness. I bought this light before I truly knew what I wanted for an EDC light and I got lucky.

Modification and uses for modification:
To make the light more useful to me I added a paracord tassel to the button end of the light as pictured. This is easy to make and actually fun to make as well you can google a tutorial. The tassel allows for many uses: 1) Allows me to hook the tassel into the collar of my shirt so I can free my hand when needed such as when I am walking my dog and need to pick up my dog's poops. 2) Helps prevent the light from rolling on slanted surfaces. 3) allows a more ergonomic way to shine the light and manipulate the button at the same time, as pictured. Holding the light this way while using it also frees up my pinky finger to hook my pepper spray with the provided keyring, as pictured, making the pepper spray easier to access when needed.

Brightness settings/light pattern
The three settings make the light very useful because you don't always need a bright light. Using a dim light when needed also saves on battery life. I use the dim light when I wake up in the early morning and need to look for something and I dont want to wake my fiancé. The brightest setting has a very far throw distance which is also contributed by the light pattern. This light uses a spot light pattern as oppose to a flood pattern. I really like this compromise because this allows the battery to last longer for its size and I rather have a far reach than a wide light pattern. This is an important tradeoff to note for all who read this.

Light activation: So keep in mind this isn't really a tactical light. There is no momentary button but be honest with yourself when you determine your needs for an everyday carry light. This may not be the best light for you if you need something for tactical purposes. its not like the click of the light button is loud either. That being said the activation of this light is very easy for its intended design.

EDC:
Unless I forget to put this light in my pocket, this light goes with me everywhere. The size is so small it doesnt bother me in any way. On weekends I will carry the light with my multitool inside a handgun magazine carrier made by Remora I have repurposed. they fit together perfectly and the whole package fits in my back pocket nicely. I have a boney butt but it doesnt bother me sitting down all day with this package in my back pocket. The tassel also makes it easy to pull out the light from the magazine carrier.

Battery life:
The battery life on this is very good. I use this light every day at least once when I take my dog out in the early mornings and I use it at the second brightness setting. Each time I'll run the light for about 5-15mins. I will usually replace the battery after a little over a month. The light will start to malfunction when the battery will start to die. You will not be able to use the brightest setting or the second brightest settings when the battery starts to die. Another advantage is the battery is very common and easy to find.

So I've had this specific light for about 5 years now. I like it so much, I've bought one for my dad, my sister, my fiancé, and future father in law. The cost may seem high but I think you get a lot for the money so to me the price is fair.

So overall I highly recommend this light if you need a good general purpose light that is compact.

reviews:
This is a fabulous light. On high (130 lumens)
the light is powerful enough to momentarily blind someone in the dark. I believe this happens above 100 lumens. The beam is narrow and right up front allowing plenty of side lighting. It tail stands well and has a hole for a lanyard. (The only way you won't lose it or misplace it.) The 3 setting allow the light to run for 1 hr at 130 lumens, 3.5hrs at 50 and 22hrs at 8 lumens on an alkaline AA. With a Ni-MH battery mid goes to 6.5hrs and an incredible 40 hrs at 8 lumens.
This means the light can run for 4 or 5 nights on low! Great night light for vacation or when your kid moves into the dorm. The 8 lumens is perfect for camping or a in a strange place like a motel!
I have illuminated 3 large rooms for hrs at 8 lumens with 5 lights. My mom is on oxygen and can't be without it. The Fenix 12 lights up a room well enough to change oxygen bottles or to read under. EVERY person should have one. Send this to your kid in college. They can read under this light. Perfect compact Do All light. Replaces candles, reading light, survival light, edc, emergency light. I keep lithium batteries and a Surefire in my car but this is what I edc.
I have 50 lights and this is the one I tell people to get 1st. You can always find AA batteries in your tv remote.

reviews:
There was a time when a 100-lumen flashlight was considered bright. My first LED flashlight was a single-mode Surefire 65 lumen model that set me back sixty bucks, burned 45-50 minutes and took an expensive CR123A battery 🔋 that cost five bucks at a drugstore (if you needed it in a hurry). I spent thirty bucks on a flash head that upgraded it to 100 lumens. Now, thanks to technology, serious emergency flashlights now (12/15) put out 1,000 lumens and have remarkable runtimes. In their wake are small, highly affordable, waterproof, tough and reliable lights that can be carried in a pocket or pocketbook and powered by cheap disposable AA/AAA batteries. The Felix E12 boasts a bright, maximum 130 lumens and two lower settings that greatly extend battery life. But even at its brightest, you can get an hour and a half runtime. And when you turn the light on, it comes on in the lowest setting, then advances with each press of the button. Maximum runtime is 40 hours at the lowest setting of eight lumens (which is bright enough to see and navigate in most instances). And with the small flash head, you'll get plenty of flood, or spill.

A few of these lights in your emergency kits at home (with batteries), and you'll be ready for ice and snow storms, hurricanes and other disasters that may result in prolonged power outages. You'll still want it's big brothers for serious emergencies, and for those I recommend flashlights like the Klarus RS-20, Nitecore SRT7, Fenix PD35 and the Olight M20/21. (The Nitecore and Olight lights have actually been used as diving lights. They're all great makes.)

great little light! perfect for a non-tractical EDC...i.e., you're not gonna go high speed operator and raid a boko haram hut with this...BUT! if you need to peer into a dark corner, looks for a leak in your engine bay or take the short cut through the woods when walking your dog at night, this flashlight excels.

oh, i've had mine for months and still havent changed the single AA battery. You EDC/TEOTWAWKI nerds need to look at this light if only because it wont use up hardly any of your doomsday battery cache when the balloon goes up. ;)

review_title: Excellent flashlight, don't bother to read this, just buy it
reviews:
Disclaimer: I don't work for them, but I am total Fenix fanboy.

I love Fenix lights and this one didn't disappoint. It is just about perfect for what it is. The button is solid, the half-depress position to change light intensity is flawless. The construction quality is the same high standard as all Fenix lights I have owned. The light stages go from dim to astoundingly bright for a single AA.

My only complaint is that the holes for the included lanyard are teeny. They work great for the lanyard, but I don't like the lanyards and prefer a small loop and clip on my lights. Rigging one to this was highly challenging and involved a lot of work with 30 gauge wire, a magnifier, needle nose pliers and tweezers. Does anyone actually use lanyards on their flashlights? I have yet to meet anyone who does, but I guess they must be out there.

As with all the Fenix AA lights, the difference between this and the cheap $10 knock offs is stark. Worth every penny and when I inevitably lose this or give it to someone who's light has broken while we are working an incident, I will rebuy it right away.

EDIT: Sadly had to remove a star. After a couple of weeks of use in a desert environment, the switch went briefly intermittent on me. After a bit it went back to working properly but apparently the switch housing isn't fully sealed. Only removing one star because I used this on low every night for a few hours for two weeks and it is still on the same battery that came with it and other than this issue it was a complete champ for my trip. Probably 30+ hours on low and at least 1 on high and still has battery charge. But switch instability, even if short lived, is a massive pain and has never happened with any of my other fenix lights in the same environment.

review_title: After several years and several lights, the E12 is still a favorite
reviews:
Being a collector of gadgets, I have a whole pile of flashlights. I was first introduced to Fenix lights years ago when I was looking at "tactical" lights. I bought one of their models that uses the CR123A batteries and that light was impressive even when compared to traditional quality brands like Surefire and Streamlight. When I began to look at lights using the more readily available and less costly AA and AAA batteries, it was a no brainer that I looked first at what Fenix offered. I bought an E12 and found it functional and reliable. As time passed and I accumulated other brands, the E12 remains one of my favorite and most used. One has ridden in my camera bag and in a carry-on bags during travel, one has been in my pocket frequently. They also serve as excellent gifts for friends and family.

There's nothing extraneous about the E12. It's simple to operate and puts out plenty of light. It uses standard AA alkalines or rechargables. It has three modes--Low, Medium and High. Low puts out enough light to see by indoors in the dark, medium puts out enough light for examination and search in low light and high is high enough for most outdoor activities at night. The beam is broad enough to cover a room and narrow enough to spot a subject outside. The light is small enough to drop in a large pocket or purse and forget it's there but it's large enough to handle and manipulate easily one-handed. There's no useless strobe or SOS function that many people only ever use by accident. This is simply a useful light for a good price.

I have smaller lights (AAA type) and I have brighter lights and I have lights with more modes but I have no more useful light than the E12.

review_title: This flashlight is amazing for the price
reviews:
I got this flashlight for EDC use after reading many reviews. This flashlight is amazing for the price. It blows away any prior EDC flashlight I had in a similar price range. Its so small and light yet still very bright and sturdy. So far I have had no issues.

As for features the one thing it lacks is a belt clip. With my last EDC flashlight I was used to clipping the flashlight to the inside of my pocket, but with the E12 I just put it in my front pocket. I wasn't sure I liked this at first, but I've already gotten used to it.

The light switch brightness settings work by pressing on and off then on again. I don't love this design (I prefer a separate way to adjust brightness, or each press to increase brightness without turning off in between) but it's pretty typical. Starting on the LOW brightness is different than my prior EDC lights which started on the HIGH setting. Starting on LOW is nice because it encourages you to preserve battery and only increase brightness if you need it, rather than default to brightest setting.

Overall I highly recommend this light for EDC, it has not disappointed me.

review_title: Wish it was more "floody", but buy it anyway!
reviews:
With so many reviews, there's very little I can add: I am very impressed, and glad I bought it. Way brighter than the 1980's 3-D cell Maglites that I thought were great about 15 years ago. There's only one negative, and it's a small one: This little flashlight is trying very hard to be a "thrower", meaning the beam is pretty narrow, with very little spill. Given that it's only 130 lumens, that's not really what it's meant for: I feel it would be a lot more useful around the house and campsite if it was more "floody" and less "throwy". But, I absolutely love that it always starts in the lowest mode, and that it has no useless strobe modes. I also like that it has a real clicky switch, not a soft switch.

Bottom line: If you want a 1xAA light, buy this one. You won't be sorry.

review_title: This is my favorite flashlight of all time
reviews: This is my favorite flashlight of all time. It's not an exaggeration to say that I use this flashlight every day. Whether it's to illuminate a quick rummage through my backpack, or to light the trail back home when I've lingered a bit too long in the woods, this light is always coming in handy. Since I don't normally need the extra output of the brighter modes, a rechargeable AA battery will last me months. If I have a gripe, it's that it didn't come with a diffuser. And that's it. Just buy this light. You won't be disappointed.

review_title: Great so far, with the possibility of premature lens wear and beam alteration.
reviews:
I've been using the E12 for a few weeks now in an every day carry/hiking role. It seems to be a very well made light, and I love having the capability to shine bright and far if needed (on high).
PROS: Well made, great size, and I like the interface.
CONS: I miss having a clip more than I thought I would. If your current light has a clip and you find yourself ever using it, you may want to pass on the E12. Rather than clipping securely to something, you're forced to let it ride in the pocket, which leads me to my next issue.
I do not know whether it came from the factory like this or not, but the lens appears to already be scuffed and scratched more than I would consider normal. To be sure, the bezel around the lens is barely raised to protect the lens, but I beat up my Pro-Tac 1AA for years and lens is still in new condition. I predict that if such scuffing continues, the beam will be altered. I plan to contact Fenix about it.

review_title: Great general purpose,multi-use AA battery flashlight
reviews: I just want to start off by saying that I am a huge fan of Fenix flashlights. Their flashlights are reliable and very sturdy - I accidently both dropped them on concrete and washed them in my washer and they still keep on working. I have their E21, LD01, and LD10 among a couple other flashlights. Each serves a different purpose and is good in their own way. But if you want an all around general purpose flashlight, you can't go wrong with the E12. It works on a single AA battery and the light is bright at 130 lumens. If you want something brighter, you would have to get a larger flashlight that takes more batteries and/or get a flashlight that takes CR123A batteries or 18650 Li-ion batteries, which can be pretty pricey. The other option is to go with the LD02 (1 AAA battery @ 100 lumens) or LD09 (1 AA battery at 130 lumens, but costs more). I am a big fan of the tactical tail switch of flashlights, which this one has. It's basically a pressable button at the end of the flashlight that let's you easily turn the flashlight on and off and/or switch between different modes/intensities of lighting. The E12 doesn't come with a case or a belt holster, which is a downer, but you can always buy it separately. All in all, I am very pleased with the E12 as a general purpose, multi-use flashlight.

I tried it a few times before putting it in the car and it has a very consistent light even on the low setting, more than enough to see where you are going at night and on high enough to blind an on looker! I would recommend it for any purpose and with a couple of extra AA batteries it would work for a month or more on a camping trip if used for normal things getting around camp an hour or so every night.

reviews: Fenix is, in my opinion, one of the best flashlight manufacturers you will find. I have a bit of a flashlight fetish, I'm not going to lie. I tend to pick them up like fast food. I always seem to have one within reach at all times. So I've tried a few. And I'm not talking the cheap ones either. I've tried expensive ones but they have all, for the most part, been flawed. Usually, it has something to do with the battery contacts failing. Then, a few years ago, I inherited my Father's Fenix and I've been a convert ever since. When I needed a small, pocket flashlight that packed a punch, I immediately went to find a Fenix and the E12 fit the bill perfectly. It has the Fenix quality construction which means that even this tiny light feels rugged. And the tail switch is great. It's flush so you can actually stand the E12 up on it's end, which I understand was a critique of the previous E11 model. You have 3 modes to select from by simply tapping (or more accurately, very lightly pressing) the button to cycle through the different light levels. I spend a lot of my day working in a very dark room and the lowest mode is plenty. But it's nice to know that the brightest mode is enough to light up the opposite end of a hallway if need be! Easy to power with 1 AA battery. It fits easily in your pocket and would be perfect for a glove compartment, purse, bug out bag or camping kit. I plan to buy several more and keep them around the house and in the cars. And a reminder that if you take a few minutes to register your light online, you'll get an extra 6 months of coverage which amounts to 30 months total of free warranty coverage.

review_title: Delightful, solid feel, excellent brightness, handy size.
reviews:
UPDATE: As of June 2016, this is still one of my two favorite lights, and my wife will tell you I have a flashlight problem. It still has the best feel in the hand, and although it's not as bright as newer-generation models, it's still excellent for its intended purpose as a very compact light suitable for everyday carry or keeping in tight places.

+++

As of February, 2015, this is my favorite small flashlight. Obviously, LED technology is advancing quickly, so the efficiency and brightness of this unit will not be competitive in a couple of years, but right now, it's very bright, uses a common AA battery, has simple operation, is very solidly built. It feels great in the hand -- very satisfying to hold.

It's not much bigger than the battery that fuels it, which makes it excellent to keep in the car or stash in key locations around the house.

My only complaint is that it starts on the low setting, which seems counter intuitive: I usually use flashlights on their brightest settings, and sometimes dial the brightness back. So I have to tap the power button three times most of the time. Not sure why Fenix chose that sequence, and I hope they don't use that default in their designs in the future. But even with that flaw, this is easily my favorite to date. Happy I have it, and I've given one as a gift to another flashlight nerd.

#576 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
This flashlight goes EVERYWHERE with me. As an RN, the low setting works great for pupil and neuro checks on patients without being painful on my patients' eyes. On medium it's more than bright enough for walking the dog and feeling secure on visibility. On high I can light up the room or see things well at the end of the yard.

And that's why I bought 2 of these babys. It's a perfectly thought out flashlight at a great price.

Here's an overview:
1. Common batteries, er, battery. AA is the most common battery out there.

2. Mode order. Low 1st. Medium 2nd. High 3rd. The quick half-click makes it quick to change modes.

3. Battery indicator. Sorta. As the battery drains, the higher settings don't come on. In other words, as you battery runs lower, the High mode will no longer turn on. Then, the Medium no longer turns on when your battery is almost drained. It gives you a heads up on the charge and keepa you from leaving you in the dark with prolonged use.

3. Build. Solid consteuction (mine has been dropped plenty of times with nothing besides a few amall scratches). Waterproof. Candle mode. Tail switch.

Love this light, it's going to be a stocking stuffer for a lot of my family this year.

review_title: Amazingly bright, long-running, and durable compact light
reviews:
Size: The light is roughly the size of a tube of lipstick, so it's easy to carry in your pocket or a bag and not even notice that it's there.

Construction/Design: The construction appears to be high-quality. The housing is solid and the action on the 3-mode button works very well. I haven't tried dropping it to test its durability, but it seems like it would handle drops OK. The light is easy to open to replace the battery but stays securely closed otherwise. The light tail-stands well when the included strap is not attached.

Run-time: The light runs for a really long time on a single battery, although I have not measured the actual run-time. I'd guess that the estimated run times from the manufacturer are accurate.

Brightness: The lowest brightness setting is great for a task light, and the highest brightness setting is amazing for such a small light.

Recommendation: I've bought 3 of these so far and really like them. Highly recommended.

reviews:
Great flashlight! It's plenty bright for a pocket flashlight, and it can fit in a man's fifth (coin) pocket. Despite that, it's large enough and has sufficient texture that my size-Large hands can easily keep hold of it. I carry it whenever I'm going out in the evening. The three brightness levels are very useful, especially since they go from lowest to highest.

The construction definitely seems sturdy, though I haven't given it an opportunity to prove that. I love that it uses a single AA battery -- in addition to being cheaper and easier to find than most other batteries, the singe AA configuration is inherently much more reliable than the triple-AAA configuration so many small/medium flashlights have now. In my experience, the AAAs in those flashlights will come loose, causing the flashlight to flicker. This flashlight won't do that.

review_title: This tiny flashlight is every bit as good as the E11 which it replaces
reviews: This tiny flashlight is every bit as good as the E11 which it replaces, with one exception. That exception is, that you cannot use the rear button to signal Morse code, nor any other thing you want to flash the light for. On the E11 predecessor, the high low beam was switched by turning the front dial, and the rear button was either momentary or permenant switch on and off. On the E12, the front dial does nothing at all, and the rear switch toggles between low, medium, and high beam. Some people might like this, but I will be keeping my E11 because I like theversatility of having two switches and being able to momentary flash the light. Both the specimens are equally fantastic in quality engineering, brightness, and tiny size. The highbeam can search the woods for an hour, and the low beam can help you read in the dark for between eight and 80 hours, depending on the model.

Great size, excellent light output (puts my 3 D-cell led retrofitted Maglite to shame) and gets daily use. I have had to put new batteries in twice at this point- once, when the light would only give medium output and another time when the light went out completely.

I use this while walking my dogs at night- my older dog can only see out of one eye, and this helps keep him from walking into things like trees and fences.

The lanyard is tough and I really cannot say enough good things about this light.

Price point is perfect, size is great, output is amazing for a single AA light and use (the on/off switch, which also changes modes) works perfectly.

reviews:
Originally, I wanted to keep the E11 as the wrist strap had broken off and I lost it. But - the E11 has essentially vanished from production. I don't like that, but I decided to try the E12.

After using it for a bit, I have to say I'm quite impressed. As also mentioned, there is no more "Tactical light" which I liked from the previous ones. Tapping the light while on intervals it through dim, brighter and brightest and resets to dim. When turned off, it resets to dim. This works well as it's not often I need to get to brighter levels and the output at the brightest is impressive considering the size of the thing.
The flashlight can now stand on end, permitting candle light usage. This was especially useful during a recent power outage. It illuminated the whole room on the dimmest mode!

As for power, I use eneloops AA which work great. It's hard to beat a very bright battery sized flashlight that's now effectively free to run!

reviews: I can't say enough good things about this light. If it wasn't $25 I would have many many more. A simple click on/off or if you want to change intensity just half press. Many lights in this category seem to be for tactical purposes with all kinds of needless (in my case) functions. review_title: EDC/Pocket flashlight thats strong and worth the money
reviews:
GREAT little flashlight. I have a variety of lights and was looking for one that would run off of a single AA battery (alkaline OR rechargeable). This little light fits easily in the coin pocket of my jeans, has a recessed on/off button and three light modes selectable by a momentary press of the button.

The light defaults to the lowest setting of 8 lumens, and the user can cycle through low/med/high. This light does not have a momentary on setting; it's either on or off.

Machining is solid as to be expected, and the o-ring feels like it's going to keep out the moisture. There is only one point where the light screws apart (to install the battery). I also thought it a nice touch that the company added an extra o-ring in with the wrist lanyard and instructions.

Good buy for the money.

reviews:
I had one of these. Lost it. Bought another one, identical light. Found the original under my bed. Now I have two identical flashlights, which is fine by me. I like the light levels. The dimmest one is good for inside at night, even a bit brighter than it needs to be for that application. The brighter two are good for when I've tied the flashlight to my bicycle handlebars as a headlight, it throws light far enough ahead to be able to avoid curbs and potholes. I replaced the battery with a standard rechargeable, which works, but the brightest level is dimmed to barely more than the medium level - I guess rechargeables can't put out the same amount of current the Edison Bright can.

It would be perfect if it had a strobe functionality, but I can't fault this little flashlight for not having a feature I could have gotten in one of Fenix's higher-end models, but didn't want to pay for. So I'm giving it 5 stars anyway.

The only gripe I have is the lens seems to be made of plastic and mine has a big scratch on it. I'd imagine if one carries this light in one's pocket or purse over the course of the light's lifetime, the lens will be so scuffed that light output will be greatly diminished. Fenix should have used glass as lens cover.

reviews:
I had never owned a Fenix flashlight before this one. I actually thought I was ordering a full size flashlight, so when I opened the box, I thought I'd made a mistake. I expected performance in line with its size. That was the real mistake! This flashlight is incredible. It's amazingly bright (as bright at a much-larger hand held spotlight I bought at the same time), beautifully made and easy to handle.The other day I had to re-wire the back of a AV Receiver. The unit is in a cabinet with zero light to read the labels on the inputs, so I just held the Fenix in my teeth and had both hands free and tons of light directed exactly where I was working.

I have just ordered two more to keep in our cars - full size flashlight performance in a pocket size light that doesn't fill up the glove box. I will never buy another brand.

review_title: I recently received this in the mail and I'm happy as hell with it
reviews: I recently received this in the mail and I'm happy as hell with it. It's small and lightweight and damn near disappears in my pocket. The grip is very nicely machined and isn't overly aggressive, but provides a high level of traction. The only (kind of) gripe that I have is that the front of the light is flush with the casing as opposed to slightly recessed, but that in no way effects the performance, just personal preference. Overall, I'd highly recommend this if you're looking for a solid, pocket light for not a lot of money.

review_title: I have had good luck with these Fenix lights (B00BNUBDKW)
reviews:
UPDATE: After using the light a little longer, I noticed one odd attribute about the light. I"m lowering the stars from 5 to 3. When you first turn on the light, it turns on in lower power mode. You have to press the button on the end cap 2 more times to get to high power. That's pretty annoying when you are working on something and you don't need the light the whole time. So, you want to turn the light off for a minute to save the battery. When you turn it back on a few seconds or minutes later, it doesn't remember you had it on high power.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: I'm not a flashlight nerd or anything. I just needed a light that would be there when I needed it. It's too early to say if that is the case. But, I'm getting tired of buying flashlights that spontaneously stop working. I have had good luck with these Fenix lights (B00BNUBDKW). So, I figured I'd take another chance on Fenix.

I can say that I'm very pleased with the light output. I think for general purpose, around the house, type usage, this light will be great. I also purchased the LD22 lights. I'll leave a review there for those.

review_title: If you only buy one light, let this be the one.
reviews: I wanted to give this 4 stars only because it doesn't have a pocket clip, but I gave it 5 stars because this fell in 2nd place as my new favorite gear in my camp/backpack kit. Runs on 1 AA! I've dropped this thing (on accident) from about 4 feet of the ground onto my kitchen hard floor, picked it back up and turned it on like nothing ever happened. Way smaller than I had imagined it being, which is a plus. I was going to get the 4sevens prion 2, but heard that it tends to get a bit hot. This light got warm after having it on high for 30-45 minutes, but that's it. I even drooled on it when I put it in my mouth to wash dishes with at night at my camp site. There is no strobe, but I seriously don't need one. It comes with a lanyard which I connected to a carabiner clip so that I wouldn't misplace it, but I still did.....and found it thankfully! If only it had a pocket clip....then I would give this 6 stars!

review_title: Not up to par with the E11 but OK.
reviews:
So, this is the replacement for the E11 - not really.

First, I gave my Daughter my old E11 because her husband kept stealing all the flashlights I gave her!!! I made her swear that she would not part with my E11 because it was the best light I had - she promised!!!

I got on Amazon to find that the E11 was not available unless you paid almost triple the value so, I looked at the "replacement" E12.

Simple makes me happy. On / off with the temporary light of the E11 was great. The E12 succumbed to the new "in vogue" of the triple level switch (8, 50 and 130 lumen) which negated the easy on / easy off and temporary light of the E11. Complex not so good.

Although I do like the fact that the levels go from low to high instead of reverse and that the tail switch only has to be barely tapped in order to roll through the levels of lumens you still have to cycle instead of the simplicity of the E11.

One other thing - there is no way that this light is 130 lumens on high. I'm betting when I see my daughter and make a side by side comparison with the 110 lumen E11 that the E11 will win the shootout!!!

That said, I will have to live with the E12's complexity and low lumen because I need a small light in my travels and this one with just 1 (one) AA battery is the best I could find.

review_title: Layard holes too small and close to switch.
reviews:
I have had the Fenix LD01 flash light for four years and liked it. I missed placed it so I ordered this one. I carry the flash light on my belt clip everyday for work. The cheap key ring finally spread opened enough on the LD01 for the lanyard to fall out causing the flash light to fall off my belt unnoticed.

When I found the my old Fenix light (in my car) I bought several flat key ring to fit through the tiny openings at the bottom of the light but all were to big to fit through the Fenix holes. I decided to not cancel the order for this flash light hoping the holes would be bigger. They are the same small size and so close to the on/off button that only the included cloth lanyard could be threaded through the holes to then clip onto a D ring and my belt.

I am buying the item below. Hoping to savage off the black lanyard hoping it will fit through the small holes by the on/off button to then attach to a D ring or a Retractable Key Ring holder that I bought to solve the problem of connecting the light to by belt. This did not work. The O ring was too big to fit through the flashlight holes.

The lanyard that comes with this light is difficult to thread through the holes by the on/off button due the small space between the button and the holes. The included lanyard will not last long with everyday wear on my belt.

Mudder 5 Pack Neck Lanyards with Detachable Buckle for Mobile Cell Phones, iPods, USB Flash Drives, Keys, ID Card (Blue)

reviews: I am a fan of Fenix flashlights. This is my third Fenix. The build quality, price, and performance are good. As for this particular model, I am satisfied with all the basics. It is bright. It can tailstand. It is small. It is inexpensive. It uses only one AA battery. It feels good in the hand. Nice metal construction. My problem with the E12 is it does not remember which of the three brightness settings you were using when the flashlight is powered off. I often want to use the brightest setting right away, and have to tap the power button three times. Some higher-end models remember the previously used brightness setting. I guess that feature was omitted to keep the cost of the E12 down. Overall, it is a fine flashlight, but I have to deduct one star.

review_title: Good for what it is, but definitely get the Olight S1 if you plan to use it at home at night.
reviews:
This is a very good EDC light. I say EDC, because it's good for every "day" carry. It's small, cheap, uses a common battery, and is bright enough.

However, it's not my every "night" carry. Most of my flashlight use is at night. Especially when others are sleeping. At its dimmest setting, this light is way too bright for navigating around the bedroom when your spouse is sleeping, and too bright for comfort when you want to go to the bathroom at night without turning on the bright lights.

I've since purchased the Olight S1, with its 0.5 lumen mode, and love it. It's now my EDC and ENC, and the Fenix is in my backpack as a spare. The S1 also goes to 500 lumens, compared to the 130 of this light. I far more often need the ultra-low setting, but it's nice to have.

If you want something cheap and good, get this. If you want something high-quality with a much wider range of uses, get the S1.

review_title: They chose the wrong lumen levels
reviews: This is an expensive flashlight for such a small simple thing. It is well made, but I think the extra money they spend, if any, is wasted on such a small item that will probably get lost easily. This is my second LED flashlight. The first was a impulse buy at Home Depot for $12 two years ago and frankly, I like that one better. It is larger, has a more useful amount of light and remembers the last used setting. The Fenix light's default setting is only 8 Lumens and I think they should have made it at least 20. The next setting is 50 Lumens and bright is 130 Lumens. Basically, the brightness increases with the ratio of one level to the next, so they chose the jump from low to medium to be about 6:1 and the jump from med to high to be about 2:1. I cannot think of a good reason to have an 8 Lumen setting other than to offer very long battery life. It is just too dim for me. On the positive side, as others have said: well made, gold plated contacts, and good light pattern.

review_title: Very good flashlight for purse or pocket -- I've given one ...
reviews: Very good flashlight for purse or pocket -- I've given one of these (ore the previous version, the E11) to several people, since it is small enough to always carry with them and is bright enough to do real good. I do wish the light initially came on as high beam, not low beam -- to get to high beam, one has to push hard once, then push gently twice (to cycle through low to medium to high beam). When I first turn on a flashlight, I almost always do it to get bright light, not to get dim light. If I want to read for many hours, then I can turn it down, but it is a little annoying to have to cycle through low and medium to get high. But I still think this is the best single AA flashlight around, and practically indestructible.

review_title: Great light at a great price.
reviews:
This is a great little flashlight. Very bright on it's highest setting. I also have an E11 and it's about the same output as the E12 on medium. The only limitation is the inability to "flash" the light as a click simply turns it to low and any subsequent light presses changes the intensity. Get an E11 if you need the ability to flash the light for signaling of some sort.

Someone mentioned that the E12 doesn't have a protected power button. Not sure if there are manufacturing differences, but mine does have a shroud on two sides of the button and will protect it from accidental presses.

reviews:
I have several single AA flashlights, and this is my favorite. It is small enough to carry in your front pocket, and appears to be good quality. 95% of the time I use it on the lowest setting. I like the fact that you can turn it off directly from low, and next time you turn it on it goes right back to the low setting. You don't have to cycle through all the settings to turn it off (like some other less expensive lights I own).

The only thing this light is missing is a clip to allow you to attach it to a ball cap to use as an improvised head lamp. Fortunately, I had a clip from an inexpensive light that stopped working. I put the clip in this light and it is my new favorite.

review_title: Excellent flashlight with great features but not as good at ...

Excellent flashlight with great features but not as good at predecessor.

Everything about this light is better than the e11 except that they eliminated the momentary-on position, requiring a full push-on to activate the light.

Excellent, non-the-less.

reviews:
I work in quality assurance and having a quality flashlight for inspections is a must. This one ticks all of boxes for me. Everyone else has big bulky flashlights that fall out of their pockets. This one is powerful enough to see into dark spaces, but small enough to go anywhere with me.

Pros:
Three light settings, with high being plenty powerful
AA battery powered for each power cell swap
Anodized aluminum body is durable
Lanyard is nice for not dropping it
Push button tail keeps accidental switch on to a minimum

Cons
Bigish hands might have a hard time holding it
Power button is a little stiff

Overall, I think it is a quality flashlight for a pocket or backpack flashlight. Don't forget, the tool you use most often is the one closet to you. And this one will not disappoint.

reviews:
I loved this flashlight for 2 days until problems developed. When I would screw it together all the way (completely tight) it would short circuit the battery. I found out about this because I thought the flashlight was off and put it in my pocket. A minute later it was blazing hot. I was able to determine that there wasn't a problem with the battery because it did the same thing with several other batteries. It worked fine as long as I didn't screw it together tightly. The o ring was in place and there was no obvious visual clue as to the cause of the short.

3 stars because it was probably just a QC issue. I didn't take my chances on an exchange. Watch out for this behavior if you buy one.

review_title: Update: Failed after 1 year of very light service - was: AA mini flashlights micro review
reviews:
Pictured left to right in the attached photo are:
* Coast HP1 Focusing 190 Lumen LED Flashlight
* Gerber Recon Multicolor Flashlight, Black [22-80016]
* LRI PPRO Proton Pro White/Red, 2-Colors-in-1 LED Flashlight, 1-Pack
* Fenix Flashlights E12 130-Lumen Flashlight, Black
* Zebralight SC52Fw L2 AA Floody Flashlight Neutral White

Here are my micro thoughts on each:
* Coast HP1 Focusing 190 Lumen LED Flashlight
3 1/2 stars
Very bright. Larger and heavier than the others.
The only one here that is focusable for distance, thus is good for illuminating long distances.

* Gerber Recon Multicolor Flashlight, Black [22-80016]
3 stars
A nice little flashlight.
Uses simple rotating color filter wheel.
Not very bright.
Good if you require white, red, blue and green illumination.

* LRI PPRO Proton Pro White/Red, 2-Colors-in-1 LED Flashlight, 1-Pack
4 1/2 stars
This has been my goto flashlight for years.
As an amateur astronomer I require both red and white light.
This product has variable brightness for both red and white LEDs, from very dim to very bright.
I ding it a half star because the firmware can be a little flaky sometimes, I think when the battery is getting low.
Overall an excellent product though.

* Fenix Flashlights E12 130-Lumen Flashlight, Black
4 1/2 stars
This is an excellent little flashlight.
Very light and small.
Very bright.
I have only owned it a short time though.
I ding it a half star because it only supports 3 brightness levels, not full variable brightness.
It is very easy to toggle between the 3 brightness levels though.
Also note that the ergonomics could be improved as it difficult to discern front from back by feel-
I find I am pushing in the lens to try to get it to turn on!

* Zebralight SC52Fw L2 AA Floody Flashlight Neutral White
4 stars
This is also a nice little flashlight.
It is quite dim in its lowest setting so this is what I use nightly around the house.
The Fenix Flashlights E12 even in its lowest setting is too bright for me around the house at night.
I love the ergonomic ribbing on the Zebralight.
It may not be bright enough in its bright setting to go camping with for example.
This flashlight has the best ergonomics of all reviewed, with a nice large easy-to-find button to turn it on.
It fits in the hand great.

Update: 11/1/2017
This flashlight was purchased 11/2016. It died 11/1/2017.
I believe the switch broke, as is reportedly common with these flashlights.
I attempted to remove the rear of the flashlight to tighten the switch assembly, a reported fix, but could not do so.
After a half-hour of trying with various vice grips it went in the recycle bin.
I am reverting to the Proton Pro, which, while its firmware is somewhat flaky, has never failed in the field under tough use.

review_title: Best small flashlight I have ever purchased, hands down.
reviews:
I recently purchased this flashlight (Fenix E-12) and I could not be happier. I have been using it frequently, and carrying it daily. It is small enough to fit easily in my pocket and makes a superb addition to what I carry every day. It feels durable, has faultless high quality construction, and is exactly the width of my palm. From an ease of operation standpoint, the button is nicely recessed, and has a full push to click on function. Once on, a further small push will enter the medium bright, and a second push into full bright modes. In full brightness mode, it is quite bright, and in a dark room, is bright enough to light up the whole room. I feel the beam is a good trade off between focus and spread for anything up to about 30 yards. It comes with a small lanyard, which I have attached but rarely use. One of my favorite features is the AA battery (it takes 1), and I haven't had to replace it yet. I looked through a lot of different options online to fit my specific requirements, and this flashlight was what I decided upon, and I am glad I did.
As a United States Marine I know the tactical utility of a quality flashlight, and this one fits the bill. As a medical student, this is a perfect addition to my patient exam gear, but is too bright to be comfortable for eye examinations. Every time someone sees it and asks about it, I confidently tell them my only problem is that I didn't order two.

review_title: Long battery life, AA powered, but not quite as bright as I expected it to be
reviews:
After reading several reviews of the E12 I decided to give it a try. I will start by saying that as always with Amazon I received the light in a timely manner and it was packaged well.

The light is very small, just a inch or so bigger than a AA battery. It seems to be well built and feels solid. I installed the battery that was included with it and immediately hit the switch to try it out. On the low setting, the light is very dim. Of course the battery life on low is something ridiculous so that's a bit of a trade off. On medium and high it is bright. Comparing it's high rating of 130 lumens to other lights I have in the 100-150 class it doesn't seem to be as bright as I would expect. Still it's bright enough for most tasks but it would not be my first pick to investigate when something goes bump in the night.

For its intended purpose of a small but adequately powered light for carrying all the time it should work well. I chose this light in part due to the fact that it uses AA batteries which can be found anywhere. I was in a new city once and trying to find replacements for cr123 batteries was impossible. The lights starts on low and you must tap the tail switch to cycle to medium and high. I would prefer it to start on high, but that's just my personal preference. I hope to update this after using the light for a few weeks.

Pros:
Size
Weight
AA battery powered
Multiple functions
Battery life

Cons:
Price
Brightness

#576 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: It's a good light, but default starting at the lowest setting is just dumb.
reviews:
It's a good flashlight,but the design is odd in that it starts on the lowest setting, and you can't adjust that default. It has 3 settings which is also stupid, since who on the planet actually uses the middle setting? Worse, it starts on the lowest setting, which is uselessly dim (for a $30 light). It doesn't remember what your last setting was. I know they say it's because that way it has the longest battery life, and doesn't overly blow out your eyes when you first turn it on, but to me, that's lame. When people want light, they want light. And making people click through the settings using the same buttons, means:

"hey what's that? I'm scared and stressed! Let me turn on my light.. damnit, too dim, ok, click up a setting... and click one mor... damnit!-turned it off. Hold on, Oh God what is that sound out there?? Ok, it's back on dim. and wait I see something clikc up one more OH NO It's off again because I'm stressed and overpressed the button! Can you hear that noise Sarah, it's getting closer! Sarah SARAH!!! OH NOOO!!!! ... "

Like I said, dumb default settings.

On a little flashlight that takes one (1) AA battery, there's no way you can make the brightest setting too bright, so just start there. For the 3 customers on the planet who somehow want a dim $30 flashlight, too bad. Instead, the other 95% of us are saddled with this annoyance, so took off 2 starts. Otherwise, it's a great light.

review_title: 高水準でまとまった性能を持つ、コンパクトライト。
reviews:
いきなりですが、悪い点から。

中心の光の強さの割に周辺への散光はかなりぼんやりしてます。ライトを進行方向に向けて歩きながら、視界の端や目線のみで足元を確認するのがやりづらいです。
屋外ではハイモードをメインに使うことになりますが、周辺光で見辛いからといって中心光で足元を照らすと、今度は眩しすぎます。

悪い点2つ目は点灯時間。
エネループプロだと入らないライトも所有しているので、エネループの標準タイプ、1900mAhのものを使っているのですが、ハイモードだと1時間と保たずにガクンと暗くなってしまいます。
130ルーメンは1AA(単３電池1本)とはいえ今どき突出した光量でもないので、点灯時間はもっと頑張って欲しいところ。

それ以外は良いライトです。
アンチロールこそ考慮されてませんが、凹凸の少ない円筒型のボディはポケットからの出し入れがしやすい。他社の1AAライトを含めても最小クラスの全長と合わさって、持ち歩きやすさは群を抜きます。
滑り止めのチェッカリングは服の繊維を引っ掻けない程度ながらも濡れた手でもしっかり保持できる絶妙さ。
深さ2mの水没にも耐える防水力は、アウトドア用としてはもちろん、水害の多い日本における防災用懐中電灯として頼もしい。
比較的小さめの中心光のおかげで、いわゆる"飛び"が良く、30mぐらい先でも人や看板など垂直な対象であればしっかり照らしだせる。
特に気に入ったのが、逆手でも順手でも明るさ切り替えと電源オンオフが出来る操作性。コレで間欠点灯と前回使った明るさを記憶する機能があれば最高だったのですが、贅沢な要望かなと。

実はかなり気に入ってるのですが、懐中電灯として重要な配光と点灯時間にやや難アリなので、星4つとさせていただきます。
その辺り改善されたバージョンが出たなら、2000円ぐらい高くても買っちゃうかも。

2016/9/28追記
自分は9/11に3000円程度で買ったんですが、なんだか5000円ぐらいに値上がりしてますね…
そこまで出すとなると、最大、最小光量の選択幅や見やすい配光で自分の中で評価の高いスルーナイトさんのArcher1AV3に勝てないかなあと。
★★★★☆という評価は3000円で買ったときのものなので悪しからず。
